rules: When committing code changes, always test the code with appropriate tools (syntax check, linting, or running tests) before creating the commit
Use clear, descriptive commit messages that explain the 'why' not just the 'what'
For multi-file changes, review all changes with git diff before committing
Always check for open GitHub issues before starting new work
When fixing bugs or adding features, reference the relevant issue number in commit messages
Prefer editing existing files over creating new ones unless absolutely necessary
Keep code changes focused and avoid unnecessary refactoring or 'improvements' beyond the scope of the task
When creating GUI applications, ensure accessibility: proper colors, readable text, keyboard support
For Python projects, always verify syntax with 'python -m py_compile' before committing
When adding new features, update relevant documentation (README, docstrings, comments)
Use meaningful variable and function names that clearly convey purpose
Handle errors gracefully with try-except blocks and user-friendly error messages
Test both mouse and keyboard inputs for GUI applications
Organize code logically: imports at top, helper functions before main logic, main execution at bottom
Use type hints in Python where appropriate for better code clarity
Keep functions small and focused on a single responsibility
Add comments only where the logic isn't self-evident
For calculator or math applications, validate input to prevent errors
Maintain consistent code style throughout the project
Before pushing to GitHub, ensure all tests pass and the application runs correctly

gitCommitTemplate.format:
Title: Brief summary (50 chars max)

Body:
- Detailed explanation of changes
- Why the changes were made
- Any breaking changes or important notes
